children.text: Thank you for downloading from the BBC. For details of our complete range of podcasts
and our terms of use, go to bbcworldservice.com slash podcasts.
I am Wali Shoaingka, standing on that same Nigerian soil where 40 years ago, what was
perhaps the first full blown civil war in post-colonial Africa took place. From Lagos,
the coastal city that was then capital of Nigeria, I undertook a visit to the secessionist
state of Biafra. Lieutenant Colonel Odumego Ujuku, once military governor of the then
eastern region of Nigeria, had become head of state of the secessionist region. My purpose
was to defuse the political standoff that was pushing Nigeria towards civil war. Last
week for the BBC World Service, I retraced my steps back to Biafra to meet Ujuku again.
And in today's programme, I am completing the round trip back to Lagos where, in 1967,
the reception was less than welcoming, as the newspaper reports of the day show.
The Sunday Post, 29 October 1967. A famous Nigerian playwright, head of drama, lecturer
and English of the Lagos University, Mr Wali Shoaingka has been detained under the emergency
regulations. Mr Shoaingka has been ominously connected with espionage activities for the
rebel leader Odumego Ujuku against the federal military government. Mr Shoaingka was also
said to have admitted in a statement that he came to an arrangement with Mr Ujuku to
assist in the purchase of jet aircraft to be used by the rebel air force. Also on August
9, Mr Shoaingka was at Benin with Colonel Victor Banjo and agreed to help in the overthrow
of the government of western Nigeria. Shoaingka further agreed to the consequent overthrow
of the federal military government, the Commissioner told the press.
Now none of this was true, but it was enough to persuade the leader of the Nigerian Federation,
General Yacubo Gawan, to have me thrown in jail.
I remember coming through this place on the way to prison. In fact, what happened was
that I went to see my doctor that day and so it was while I was there that orders were
given that I should be taken straight from there to prison. It was a very strange feeling
coming through this very busy, throbbing, noisy, raucous place, wedged in on both sides
by two secret police, I think they were then called the E branch, if I remember right,
and on either side, one in front, absolutely hemmed in. I am very conscious of the fact
that I was leaving this boisterous vitality to be mirrored behind walls.
So this is the maximum, standing outside the maximum security prison where I came. This
place is on the very outskirts of Lagos. Let me ask this gentleman where the water is.
Where is the water? Where is the lagoon? About how many kilometers?
About 5 kilometers.
Almost?
About 5 kilometers.
About 5 kilometers, yes. It is right on the outskirts of Lagos itself, the island, which
I suppose is why it was picked, so it is pretty secure. If you were not regarded as a subversive,
if you earned your sentence and you were just serving time, it was quite normal. Here
it was not too bad because I still had books, I could read, but I was cut off completely
from society, I wasn't allowed to receive letters, I wasn't allowed to make any, you
know, to communicate with the other prisoners, but of course they came fast. Inside prison
it is a totally different world. Altogether I was in prison how many months, two years,
four months, of which 22 were in solitary confinement.
To complete my journey back in time to the events of the Biafran war, I have asked to
meet General Gowan and he has agreed. So, first of all, I want to know what made him
decide that I had to be locked up.
The report that came to me actually that in the end made me to give the go ahead for your
incarceration. He became my guest. For how many is it?
Total two years and four months.
Two years and four months. But really that was done, the report was that yes, you have
been going and meeting with Ojukwu and Banjo. I think if you remember some of the bombing
that had taken place on Moloni Street very near the police headquarters, you remember
that, and the cinema in Iyaba. And all this was stated to be his hand to work. You know,
this rebel rouser.
You see what evil reputation they give me.
And I said, my goodness. So, we thought the best thing to do is go and give him a good
rest.
The story of the Biafran war can be told through the two main players, General Yakubo Gowan
on the Nigerian Federation side and Ndumengu Ojukwu on the separatist side. For his part,
General Gowan rejects any suggestion that he would have willingly embarked on hostilities
and points out that it was the Igbo who felt insecure, for reasons he acknowledged were valid.
Let's say this, to start off with, the idea of fighting a war, a civil war in Nigeria,
was never one's thought or idea when one became head of state. It was the circumstances
of the time and the belligerence of my brother and colleague Emeka Ojukwu at the time. I
would give it to him with what had happened in Nigeria at the time, all the unfortunate
killings, especially of Igbo's in most parts of Nigeria, especially in the north. And the
initial political crisis due to the killing of the various political leaders in the north
and some of the senior military officers. Now, all these things probably either made
for the Igbo's to feel very unsafe and unsure of being Nigerians and they would rather probably
have a home of their own. But Ojukwu in the end, despite all the effort that we tried
to try and resolve the problem, to reassure, I think he had a different idea. Personally,
I think he had a different idea. He wanted to really break up and have a home for the
Igbo's or Easterners on their own.
The army had professed to turn Nigeria into a land where no one should feel a stranger
in their own country, where he would be free to live and work anywhere he liked, be proud
to be a Nigerian and move about anywhere without fear or molestation, discrimination or oppression.
Sad to relate, the events of May, July and September 1966 and thereafter have since shattered
those pious hopes and plunged Nigeria into uncertainty, drift and confusion.
Wanton and premeditated acts of destruction against this region and its peoples have compelled
them to reappraise their attitudes. We have reached a stage where I am unalterably convinced
that to save the very semblance of Nigeria as one country, we must drift a little apart.
The words of Odunego Ojukwu reflecting on the horror felt by the Eastern people, the Igbo especially,
towards the terrible injustices they had undergone. Today for the BBC World Service, both Ojukwu
and Gowon reflect on the time that they actually met to try and save the country from descending
into chaos and civil war. This was the meeting in Aburi, Ghana in 1966.
We went indeed to Aburi with two different mindsets. You could even see it in the way
we appeared. The Nigerian contingent at Aburi in front of that pedra, said lodge, and I
saw them there in their flowing robes. They had become the new Nigerian politicians. I
came in jeans and a shirt, great contrast with my colleagues, that is true. We got in.
I had clearly in my mind what I wanted to achieve. I make no bones about it. I wanted
greater autonomy for the people of Eastern Nigeria. I am glad that right now as you and
I are talking, we can still summon and get the records of Aburi. And one thing I'm sure
will be clear to you that every word I spoke was chosen to secure for the people of the
East, Eastern Nigeria, greater, greater, greater autonomy.
The agreement was that when we come back, I'm going to make a statement on what we agreed
to do. And then after that, the other governors will then make their statement. Unfortunately,
when I came back, I had a very bad fever and I could not really do what the famine could
have done on the following day. But meanwhile, when he arrived back in Inugu, he made a statement
virtually trying to commit the rest of us to his idea of the meeting, saying that we've
agreed to move apart and we've agreed to confederation and all this sort of thing,
which I can assure you that was not the agreement. And of course, it was early hours of the morning
that one of the governors, Ejo Benin in the Midwest then, rang me to say that have I had
what has happened? So I said no, like what? He said this is what Ojukwu had said. So I
said, but David, is that exactly what we said? Was that what we said? I said that is not
true. And as a result of this, I said, well, I don't know what Ojukwu means by this because
he has now created a situation which is not acceptable to the rest of us. But he's already
given the impression that that was the correct thing.
I chose the words deliberately. I used them deliberately. I'm not going to apologize for
that because I went there for effect. I went there as a leader of a people being massacred
to win for them as much freedom as I could. Sometimes I will even use words deliberately
that could be ambiguous. But it did not change the fact that this is what we agreed at that
time. And the general, the normal interpretation of what we agreed were in line with my position.
Yet if Gawan says that he got back to Nigeria and then realized that he sold Nigeria down
the garden path, that's his own business, it could have been. I'm not going to apologize
for using words that he didn't understand. But what we decided, what I got as a decision
from a brewery were exactly what I interpreted when I got back. And they are still today
what any normal person would interpret by reading the records. It was because Ojukwu
had really wanted to break away that I was forced in the end to say that no, that cannot
happen. Then if you remember immediately after the meeting about a month later, trying to
see whatever we can do to come closer together, what we received from the other side is like
hijacking and the first hijacking of any aircraft in the world actually took place in Nigeria.
I think this may not have been noticed because we had to take the matter up with the Interpol
meeting, but this was some of the things that he did, taking over the post office,
the railway stock, etc. Really making sure that there is no federal authority at all.
So something had to be done and at every move that we did, he got to know about it and he
seemed to be a step ahead. We must separate politically, we must have an international
voice so that should it ever occur again we can cry out to the world and the world to
listen that genocide is being committed, that such hideous crimes are being committed here
and we feel that we should be able to call on the help of the world. We will defend our
sovereignty, we will continue to do what is right. While we have sought peace at Nyami
and Addis Ababa, the rebels have acquired more sophisticated arms and increased their
activity. Obviously the federal government must act in time to prevent a sharp deterioration
in the military situation. Together with my colleagues in the Supreme Military Council
and the armed forces, we have therefore resolved that we must now press on with all our might
to defeat the rebels militarily and remove all traces of the tyranny and terror of the
rebel regime from the face of this country.
Listening to me, Wallace Oinka on the BBC World Service, speaking to both General Gowon
of the Nigerian Federation and Adumae Guo Juku of the Biafran Separatists, 40 years
on from the civil war.
Look at what's happening today in Iraq. When the US went in, and it's satnolic by them
today, they had no post-war strategy. None whatsoever. They just said, come in, occupy,
dictate, and of course end the morass. But you evolved this no victor, no vanquished.
I was curious, was it towards the end of the war that you began to think what happens after?
Because by now, towards the end it was clear that the Afro-Nusans were militarily defeated.
Well, right from the beginning, I know that it is not a war against the evils. So there
was no intention of fighting to just defeat the evils and to humiliate them. But I saw
it more as a fight between brothers. Yes, you can fight, but if you are a true brother,
you can fight, but in the end, you know, make it up. So right from the beginning, I think
the idea of ensuring that it is not a punitive action against the people, we had hoped that
in the end, you know, we'll be able to sit back and look back and even joke about it.
He certainly thought the slogan, no victor, no vanquished, put him in line, sort of in
the same, not Washington, but Lincoln in America. He was one of the magnanimous victors of our
civilization. Did Gawain, when he was saying it, really understand what it meant, no victor,
no vanquished? Did Haziop till today, has he thought back? How much did he do to make
the victor not a victor? On the other side, we the vanquished certainly have so many steps
of Nigeria that remind us that we are vanquished. I meant every word of it, every word of it.
I was really convinced that the only way to assure both sides is to make a statement like that,
no victor, no vanquished, but victory for Nigeria and for common sense and for humanity.
Now, those were the end because it at least stopped the suffering, the killings, and now, of course,
we know that then we have a very important thing to get down to, to reconcile ourselves.
That's why I wanted to know how early that slogan, that was a reality for you, and how early you really,
even during the war, saw this as the end to which the is-violent means, no, must be led.
But it doesn't mean that there were no atrocities. I still remember what happened in Asaba,
you know, very well documented and so on.
Absolutely, and I'm sure you probably had what I said years later when I visited Asaba at the palace.
These were some of the sort of things that happened and the commander is not informed.
And I felt so bad that years later when the opportunity presented itself, you know,
I had to say that I have learnt only of recent, learnt of what had happened,
and I could not honestly believe that such a thing could have been done by federal forces.
Certainly, such a thing should not have even happened, but it did happen,
and I had to really make a public apology that that was certainly not my order.
It was unfortunate, but they had to forgive, and I think this is what all Nigerians have to learn,
to forgive one another and to put the past behind the best they can.
It is easy to say this should never have happened, that it was preventable from the beginning,
but one would then have to ignore the histories, the complexities of nation becoming.
With Nigeria in mind, I still find myself riveted by the events that tore Yugoslavia apart,
reflecting on both divergences and similarities in the history of both nations.
Historians will always indulge in tidy theories,
but ultimately every single arena of civil war is virtually a unique planet,
where the combatants who appeared to speak the same language only yesterday
are suddenly bereft of a common tongue.
The only language that remains common to both is that of human suffering, wastage and destruction.
They may still cohabit, but a faith in community,
the building block for the so-called nation state, is lost forever.
That, for me, remains the real tragedy of civil conflict.
For more UN videos visit www.un.org
